summary: Born and raised in Brooklyn, N.Y., Christopher Wallace (Jamal Woolard) parlays his gift for storytelling into a career as a rap artist. Eventually dubbing himself Biggie Smalls, then later, the Notorious B.I.G., Wallace's tales about violent street life take him to the top of the rap charts. The subject he so often raps about catches up with him in March of 1997, when he is shot to death after leaving a party.

reviews.content: Top notch acting. Real influencer to Hip Hop culture. Real hip hop music. Tearjerker. All in 1.
This was the best movie I've ever seen the story behind biggie smalls almost 100% accurate

Hip hop finally gets a worthy drama with this very good bio-film of Christopher Wallace, aka Notorious B.I.G. Director George Tilman, Jr., who did the wonderful 'Soul Food', handles the life of Biggie Smalls with style, wit, and a light edge. He makes this story entertaining, informative, and moving. The screenwriters stay true to many of the facts concerning Biggie's life and career (all dramatized to poignant effect) and don't shy away from his rough, impulsive, brutish side. There have been many films and TV programs about Wallace before, but the writing gives us a bit of a different Biggie than we've seen before: he's funny, charming, sometimes brash, a bit cocky, and somewhat ominous. Forget the familiar story arc, obvious foreshadowing, and small patches of weak dialogue--the film hinges on the casting, especially that of the title role. Unknown Jamal Woolard (a rapper who goes by the name of Gravy) brings this icon to vivid life. He perfectly nails Biggie's personality, and utterly resembles him, physically and vocally. He carries the film well. Derek Luke is a lot of fun as the charismatic Sean "Puff Daddy" Combs, cutting loose on the man's style and high-charge energy. Anthony Mackie is impressive as Tupac Shakur. Naturi Naughton and Antonique Smith are both great as Lil Kim and Faith Evans, respectively. Angela Bassett, always classy, shines as Biggie's stern yet loving mother. It doesn't reveal too much we don't know about this infamous cultural legend, but as far as hip hop-themed films go, this one ranks as definitive
Whether the movie could have been better is debatable...but what isn't is the extraordinary life of an influential musician.
I like the story and it was interesting to so a bio-pic of Biggie Smalls.

Excellent biopic about the legendary rapper. It stays pretty conventional for this genre of film, but it does an amazing job of highlighting the rise and fall of Biggie Smalls. It also packs a potent emotional punch in regards to the legacy left behind.

I watched this over Mother's Day—man, it would've hit differently any other day. I don't know how accurate the film was as far as biopics go but it was aight. For someone like B. I. G. who was large and in charge, as well as lived large, his biopic dwarved before him disproportionately. I mean, it was never supposed to live up to anything—and I haven't really listened nor have I found new religion—Biggie deserved something more of a cable channel filler kinda thing.
A safe but interesting film This Drama is a movie that I might not watch again from time to time but I did like it and I'll give it a second watch
It's aight but why they gotta cast Anthony Mackie as Pac like 🤨
It feels like your reading a boring book

Story/Screenplay: (2.5/5) A highly formulaic biopic that still works because it is a formula that is known to work.  However, biopics work best if they are as close to "true" as possible.  In this, the formula clashed somewhat with the true, bending the portrayal of B.I.G. and ignoring some of the more unsavory aspects of his life.

Duration/Tempo: (2.5/5) At 2 hours and 2 minutes, it's a long movie that felt very long.  There was plenty of worthwhile content here, but the film could have benefited by a more aggressive edit.

Cast & Crew: (3.5/5) Jamal Woolard, Derek Luke, Naturi Naughton, and Anthony Mackie all did well.

Summary: (3/5) The cast was good, but the story could have been better and the film felt long.  A thumbs down.

Although I'm definitely talking in a subjective manner, because I am a premium Biggie Smalls fan, but I must say that this movie was very entertaining. It's one of the best biopics I've seen. It shows us the struggles and successes that the rapper went through during his short life. The film surprisingly takes some good time to develop the early history of the rapper, at the beginning of the movie. Jamal Woolard is very good at portraying Biggie. Angela Bassett as the rapper's mother is also strong. Notorious is an exciting and fascinating movie, full of good music, energy, and also tackles themes of masculinity and the pursuit of dreams. Overall, this movie is very good, and is a must-see for fans of the titular rapper. And others should also see this pic, it's very informative! Recommended!!

Actors looked like who they were supposed to. Even the main actor sounded and looked like Biggie (at least somewhat). The rapping scenes were nicely done. Respect was done for major moments in Biggie's life.

4/5. RIP Biggie.

Never making it of the ground level, 'Notorious' fails to fully express the grandeur of Biggie Smalls. Jamal Woolard at times comes eerily close to a level of verisimilitude that lends the film authenticity, but sadly the rest of the cast doesn't live up to his potential. The main problem with the story is its intention to give an overall look, thus sacrificing the moment to moment drama that could have been more resonant. 'Notorious' instead comes of a largely basic portrait filled with the usual narrative elements one would come to expect from a music biopic, and given the subject, that's a shame. While the film is photographed well, the direction is nondescript lacking for depth and true insight.

Drected by George Tillman Jr. (Soul Food (1997), Men of Honor (2000) and Faster (2010)), this biopic about rapper The Notorious B.I.G. was in development for years, and a number of directors including Spike Lee and Antoine Fuqua, before Tillman signed up. It's careful to being respectful of it's subject, but at the end of the day, it's another rags to riches biopic tinged with tragedy and hardship. Christopher Wallace (Jamal Woodard) grew up in Brooklyn with his mother Voletta (Angela Bassett), at the time during the mid 1980's, there was a "crack epidemic" in America, and Christopher ends up being a dealer on the streets, and his mother kicks him out when she discovers what he's doing, Christopher even spends time behind bars for dealing. However, Christopher has a talent for rapping, and he's discovered by Sean Combs (Derek Luke), who has Christopher signed up to Bad Boy Records, and Christopher becomes The Notorious B.I.G. But, dark times lie ahead after he meets West Coast rapper  Tupac Shakur (Anthony Mackie). It's a very good film, and you don't have to know or even like rap music to get at what Tillman and his team have made here, it captures the era well, and the film was even produced by Wallace's mother, as well as Sean Combs. Plus, Wallace's own son, Christopher Wallace, Jr. plays his own father when he was a boy.

While it was a good idea to make a biopic about one of the greatest hip hop artists ever, Notorious was lacking many elements about Notorious B.I.G.'s life, making it feel unfinished.  To it's credit, Jamal Woolard is great as B.I.G. and the performances from the cast are solid.  Unfortunately it feels more like a generic crime drama rather than a biopic.  The movie seems to focus more on the negative side of B.I.G.'s life and personality rather than the positive.  Notorious had great potential but ultimately felt too modest.

Anthony Mackie is poorly miscast as Tupac Shakur though, and the film sugarcoats the life of Christopher Wallace a bit too much.  It feels like the filmmakers were willing to only go so far in painting a true portrait of the man.  The finale of the film is quite good however and it does show that a hip hop legend is truly missed.

George Tillman Jr.'s "Notorious," a by-the-numbers biopic about the life of Brooklyn rapper Christopher "Notorious B.I.G." Wallace (1972-1997), is sure to only please the members of his core fan-base, myself amongst one of them. In March 1997 Biggie Smalls was shot and killed in Los Angeles, California, just seven months after his friend and fellow rap artist Tupac Shakur (1971-1996) was shot and killed in Las Vegas.Many thought that their murders were part of the whole East Coast/West Coast rivalry between rap artists during the mid '90s. Both Big and Tupac became the unlikely martyrs of gangsta rap and the violence that characterizes it. What's most shameful about that is that over a decade after their deaths, it seems that the hip-hop community has yet to learn a very valuable lesson.But I'm getting off-track. "Notorious" is a well-made and well-acted movie. Unfortunately, however, it's too by-the-numbers and follows the tried-and-true methods of most biopic storytelling: it glamorizes the life of the character, goes from one success to another, and doesn't really shed anything new on the person the movie is about. Of course it traces the beginnings of Biggie's life, from growing up as a bright Catholic school student in Brooklyn raised by his loving mother Voletta Wallace (a perfectly cast Angela Bassett), to his dropping out of school at age 17 to sell crack on the streets to help feed his baby daughter, and his eventual being signed to the then-newly formed Bad Boy Records by his best friend Sean "Puffy" Combs (Derek Luke). The rest, as they say, is history.I also forgot to mention that Jamal Woolard, as Biggie, who is also an aspiring rapper himself, is probably the best thing about this movie. He really captures the essence, and character of Big, and not only does he look like him, but he also talks AND sounds like him. And his skills on the microphone are undeniable as well. He lends some authenticity to the film's rhyming sessions, rapping to the songs of the real-life Notorious B.I.G., and he pulls it off magnificently. It's a star-making performance that unfortunately gets overshadowed by too many of the film's flaws.The script (co-authored by Biggie's biographer Cheo Hodari Coker) skips from one success to another; that's the biggest problem with most biopics. Another problem I had was that the portrait of the main character was pretty one-sided. While I personally consider his debut record "Ready to Die" to be one of the most important and significant rap albums ever recorded - it helped return the East Coast rap scene to prominence - I'm not totally certain that he was truly one of the greatest rap artists who ever lived, especially after only two finished recordings. And I really would have liked to have seen more of Big's friendship with Tupac Shakur (Anthony Mackie), which I felt was one of the most overlooked and tragic aspects of his life during the East Coast/West Coast rivalries. (People often forget that not only were they friends early on, but they were very close friends.)And while I'm quite certain that the sex appeal of Lil' Kim (Naturi Naughton) is one of the reasons for her success as a rapper, I also feel that one of the reasons she's here, apparently, is to show A LOT of skin and seem like the biggest, baddest 'ho in hip-hop (that's debatable). Big's relationship with wife Faith Evans (Antonique Smith) was not all that well-developed either, as was Big's friendship with Puffy, or the members of Junior M.A.F.I.A., who he helped to promote along with Lil' Kim, whom he was carrying on an affair with while still married to Faith. I also would have liked to have seen some of the paranoia and fear that gripped Biggie in the final months of his life as well, and a little bit more on the aftermath of his murder.Like I said earlier, I'm a fan of the Notorious B.I.G. myself, and so I'm sure that I'm one of those people that would have liked "Notorious" a lot more. That's the biggest tragedy about his life and this film. His short life and violent death made him one of the most important, and tragic, figures in hip-hop. I also think it's a disgrace that not much has been done by law enforcement officials to try to solve his murder, or Tupac's for that matter, and the questions revolving around the involvement of corrupt police officers in both killings have yet to be followed up in any significant fashion by anyone.I'm not going to be a cliché: I don't think he was one of the greatest rappers, personally, but the impact of his music on the industry cannot be denied by anyone: he helped the East Coast's rise back to the top of the rap scene in the mid '90s. As for the movie about his life, on the hand, it could have been better - a lot better.7/10

Based in part on hip hop journalist Cheo Hodari Coker's book "Unbelievable" filmmaker George Tillman Jr. helms the narrative with a loose, easy flow (similar to Wallace's rhyming style) despite the often stormy nature of the rapper's short life. "Notorious" 122 minute runtime ultimately comes off like the roller coaster ride Biggie's life was; filled with highs, lows, laughing, and screaming but just when things start to get fun again the ride ends. Co-star Derek Luke turns in a likable on screen impression of rap mogul Sean "Puffy" Combs.

A faithful and compelling interpretation of the life of the Notorious B.I.G., and will provide insight into the rapper's relatively short life into those closely familiar to him. Jamal Woolard is perfect for the role - he's even the exact same height as the 6'3" Biggie Smalls.
Interesting and fun to rehash great moments in music as they play before your eyes, but the characters selected to perform here, terrible.

While some parts of the film seemed embellished, overall I found it seemed quite realistic, and it seemed to inject a lot of life into the role of somebody a lot of people would quickly dismiss as just another hip-hop stereotype. The film seemed slow to start but the drama managed to build up toward the end, though the ending itself didn't seem to provide much of a satisfying conclusion.

By-the-numbers biopic, done competently enough to be watchable, but told in a very conventional, often bland way. Jamal Woolard, though serviceable, doesn't bring any real depth or nuance to the role that would elevate an otherwise lackluster film. The script hits on all the familiar beats for such a story, but never really gives the film any cohesive narrative that would be a compelling story even if it wasn't a biopic, it simply goes from scene to scene, all with an obvious and contrived feel. While enjoyable enough to stick with it, its lack of ambition or inspiration is frustrating. 

3/5 Stars

Nothing revolutionary but none the less a good film. Following the life and death of slain rapper The Notorious BIG. A must see for Hip Hop & Biggie fans alike. Jamal Woodlard is brilliant as Biggie but the film is ultimately let down by the supporting cast. Angela Bassett, who portrays BIG's mother Voletta Wallace in the film gives a dismal performance that seemed to make the film drag on and on whenever she was involved.

The pacing of this film was too slow; it seemed like one of the longest two hour films I have ever seen. The acting in the film was about average. Angela Bassett and Naturi Naughton did amazing jobs but Derek Luke could not pull off P. Diddy. George Tillman should have just hired the real Diddy to act as himself in this film. Also, the person who played Tupac was the worst. I am sure they could have found someone else. If I wasn't a big Biggie Smalls fan, I probably would have hated this film. It could have been much better but it wasn't horrible.
The story of an amazing rapper. R.I.P. Biggie Smalls

I caught the Director's cut of this film. It's a good movie but not a great one, it's kind of insightful but at the same time it isn't, It's a bias movie dat flips a few facts 2 make a certain few look like they had nothing 2 do with the shit that went wrong in his life.
I'm sure fans will love the film because its very well made, Die hard fans I think will have the same problems with the film dat i did, But da guy they got 2 play biggie was awesome, I think he did tremendous job.

This engrossing, if slightly melodramatic, biopic tells the rough story of Biggie Small's too-short life straight.  Though it skews slightly to the nicer side of the former crack dealer turned rapper, "Notorious" covers some pretty rough stuff in its lengthy 122 minutes.  All the drug dealing and adultery is almost too much to look past, but the movie manages to put the music (and talent) front and center.  Stirring performances from Jamal Woolard and Angela Bassett help the film earn its recommendation.
Well made tale of the life and death of rap icon.  Well paced story, but starts seeming a bit long near the end.
Whether the movie is true to life or not, it was a decent film. I have always been an Angela Bassett fan and she was the reason I saw this. Much better than I thought it would be.

wasn't sure if this was going to be like a tv movie or like walk the line.  is better than the former but not quite the latter.  fans of the late biggie smalls will most likely love this - i was a fan of his music so it was interesting to see what kind of person he was.  biggie was played by an unknown named jamal woolard and he did a spot-on impersonation of him.  with all the negativity that surrounded him he wasn't able to chase away his demons.  it's too bad b/c his music really was pretty good...

This one of those hilariously shoddy biopics that desperately tries to assert morality into a wholly unsavoury tale, while grotesquely massaging the posthumous ego of B.I.G - an unequivocally nasty man, who despite bringing some semblance of respect to the East Coast rap scene, was ultimately a misogynistic, nihilistic bastard who absolutely kept in regular contact with his mum. Hilariously confused sequences include a young drug-dealing Biggy ruthlessly dealing crack to a pregnant addict - much to the disgust of his unusually responsible corner-boy pal D-Roc, only to find that later she is apparently completely recovered - child in toe - dancing ecstatically down the streets of Brooklyn, seemingly unharmed by Biggies earlier transgression. Que an outrageously smug shot of Biggy looking like a self-righteous pimp, who presumably foresaw this outcome and therefore learned nothing from it. This is one of many examples of the filmmaker's (not coincidently Puff-Daddy-Diddy-Dirty-Money and Biggie's own mother) attempts to glorify his street image while simultaneously assuring us of his innocence and naivety up until his tragic and violent demise as a consequence of the East-West Coast beef that was in reality not entirely discouraged by his party. Woolard does well in the lead roll, while Mackie makes a charismatic Tupac and Antonique Smith a lovely Faith Evans. Derek Luke, however, is infinitely more handsome and less sleazy than Sean "Diddy" Combs and one imagines is more like the latter's bloated image of himself than that of actual reality. The tunes are, of course, incredible and the only reason to endure this dire, sycophantical nightmare.
one of the best biopics everrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr

Very brief and unclear in parts meaning the death etc doesn't seem clear although I think the end is brilliantly directed and done, the acting is brilliant especially the woman who plays the mum (Angela Bassett)- brilliant there, but things feel empty. The music's great though.

A bit biased since it's produced by Puffy. But a light hearted look into the life of a rapper that I grew up wtih. There's a grittier real life documentary called "Biggie and Tupac" which shows a more real life story of how he grew up.

12 Years ago Christopher Wallace was gunned down, since then he has been a cultural icon.  The film's tale of crack dealing made good is sometimes a little too hokey for its own good. Notorious is a biographical film about the rapper Notorious, how he came to fame, and his death. It's pretty educational regarding his life, I learned a lot of things I didn't know. 

Something that really bothers me about movies based on real life is when the characters don't look anything like who they're supposed to be. The only person who really looked like who they were supposed to was Notorious, but everyone else was confusing. A lot of the time I was just waiting for someone to call somebody else by their names before I knew what was going on. That was really frustrating for me. 

Another thing I've heard is that it doesn't capture the amazing personality of Notorious, and I kind of understand. It does capture a little bit of it though, for sure. The film didn't really make me understand how he became so famous and loved so fast. It tried to say it, but it was way too vague and quick about it. There was too much focus on his love life and not enough on his career, in my opinion.

The plot was interesting. It's made even more interesting because it's true. I liked the story-telling techniques by the director, but I feel like he could have done better. There were some things that needed more explaining, and some things that needed less. It's all right.

The music is great, but of course, only if you like rap. If not, you probably won't have a good time. I really love Biggie's style and I think he was really skilled, so I really enjoyed watching the parts when he was rapping. It has a great soundtrack. 

Main point, I liked this film. It had beautiful shots and a nice style. It captured the streets of New York and the dangers of the gangster life. I'm not saying it's the best one ever, but it was a little better than decent. I recommend it for a rent or to borrow from a buddy, but I probably won't be buying it soon. I'm not sure though...I did really like it.
Insightful biopic with good performances..we can only hope it is accurate...good watch overall!

George Tillman Jr.'s "Notorious," a by-the-numbers biopic about the life of Brooklyn rapper Christopher "Notorious B.I.G." Wallace (1972-1997), is sure to only please the members of his core fan-base, myself amongst one of them. I was 11 in March 1997 when Biggie Smalls was shot and killed in Los Angeles, California, just seven months after his friend and fellow rap artist Tupac Shakur (1971-1996) was shot and killed in Las Vegas; Tupac died the day after my 11th birthday in 1996.

Many thought that their murders were part of the whole East Coast/West Coast rivalry between rap artists during the mid '90s. Both Big and Tupac became the unlikely martyrs of gangsta rap and the violence that characterizes it. What's most shameful about that is that over a decade after their deaths, it seems that the hip-hop community has yet to learn a very valuable lesson.

But I'm getting off-track. "Notorious" is a well-made and well-acted movie. Unfortunately, however, it's too by-the-numbers and follows the tried-and-true methods of most biopic storytelling: it glamorizes the life of the character, goes from one success to another, and doesn't really shed anything new on the person the movie is about. Of course it traces the beginnings of Biggie's life, from growing up as a bright Catholic school student in Brooklyn raised by his loving mother Voletta Wallace (a perfectly cast Angela Bassett), to his dropping out of school at age 17 to sell crack on the streets to help feed his baby daughter, and his eventual being signed to the then-newly formed Bad Boy Records by his best friend Sean "Puffy" Combs (Derek Luke). The rest, as they say, is history.

I also forgot to mention that Jamal Woolard, as Biggie, who is also an aspiring rapper himself, is probably the best thing about this movie. He really captures the essence, and character of Big, and not only does he look like him, but he also talks AND sounds like him. And his skills on the microphone are undeniable as well. He lends some authenticity to the film's rhyming sessions, rapping to the songs of the real-life Notorious B.I.G., and he pulls it off magnificently. It's a star-making performance that unfortunately gets overshadowed by too many of the film's flaws.

The script (co-authored by Biggie's biographer Cheo Hodari Coker) skips from one success to another; that's the biggest problem with most biopics. Another problem I had was that the portrait of the main character was pretty one-sided. While I personally consider his debut record "Ready to Die" to be one of the most important and significant rap albums ever recorded - it helped return the East Coast rap scene to prominence - I'm not totally certain that he was truly one of the greatest rap artists who ever lived, especially after only two finished recordings. And I really would have liked to have seen more of Big's friendship with Tupac Shakur (Anthony Mackie), which I felt was one of the most overlooked and tragic aspects of his life during the East Coast/West Coast rivalries. (People often forget that not only were they friends early on, but they were very close friends.)

And while I'm quite certain that the sex appeal of Lil' Kim (Naturi Naughton) is one of the reasons for her success as a rapper, I also feel that one of the reasons she's here, apparently, is to show A LOT of skin and seem like the biggest, baddest 'ho in hip-hop (that's debatable). Big's relationship with wife Faith Evans (Antonique Smith) was not all that well-developed either, as was Big's friendship with Puffy, or the members of Junior M.A.F.I.A., who he helped to promote along with Lil' Kim, whom he was carrying on an affair with while still married to Faith. I also would have liked to have seen some of the paranoia and fear that gripped Biggie in the final months of life as well, and a little bit more on the aftermath of his murder.

Like I said earlier, I'm a fan of the Notorious B.I.G. myself, and so I'm sure that I'm one of those people that would have liked "Notorious" a lot more. That's the biggest tragedy about his life and this film. His short life and violent death made him one of the most important, and tragic, figures in hip-hop. I also think it's a disgrace that not much has been done by law enforcement officials to try to solve his murder, or Tupac's for that matter, and the questions revolving around the involvement of corrupt police officers in both killings have yet to be followed up in any significant fashion by anyone.

I'm not going to be to a cliché: I don't think he was one of the greatest rappers, personally, but the impact of his music on the industry cannot be denied: he helped the East Coast's rise back to the top of the rap scene in the mid '90s. As for the movie about his life, on the hand, it could have been better - a lot better.
A biopic that needs to be seen in order to understand the life and times of Notorious BIG.
it surprised me that it was as good as it was and not just because of the sex scene, ijust wonder if his death was that quiet because he looked like a balloon deflating

He was known as the Notorious B.I.G., a man-mountain of rap, but behind the image was Christopher Wallace, an overgrown kid who was trying to grow up and do the right thing. The image we know about. The film "Notorious" is more interested in the kid. He was born in Brooklyn, loved his mother (a teacher who was studying for a master's degree), got into street-corner drug dealing because he liked the money, performed rap on the street and at 20 was signed by record producer Sean Combs. Four years later, he 
was dead. Documentaries about B.I.G. have focused on the final years of his life. "Notorious" tells us of a bright kid who was abandoned by his father, raised by a mother from Jamaica who laid down the rules and told the kids on the playground he would be famous some day. "You too fat, too black and too ugly," a girl tells him. He just looks at her. He is sweet-tempered, even after being seduced into the street-corner crack business, but he sounds tough in his rap songs -- tough, introspective, autobiographical and a gifted writer.
          In "Notorious," they show how talent can lift a kid up off the street corner, but can't protect him in a culture of violence. The whole gangsta rap posture was dangerous, as B.I.G. and Tupac proved.

As a big fan of The Notorious B.I.G., I was very excited on seeing this biopic film.  The soundtrack was great, and the scene showing 2pac get shot was a great scene. However the acting was very corny, and the story line was very one-sided.  This movie had a ton of potential but from what I think, didn't really follow through.  If you like biggie, and haven't yet seen this film, I guess it might be worth a watch, but it's not as good as it could of been.

Your standard run-of-the-mill biopic. Woodward got the voice down, but all the movie did was make me want to listen to Biggie. The best part is when Big's mom tells him she threw out a plate of "old mashed potatoes" that was under his bed, which was  in fact a whole lot of cocaine. Cue laugh track.

While it was pretty much what those who payed attention to the news during the 90s expected, it was done rather well. Aside from the fact that most of the actors looked very little like there real life counterparts(I know people who look more like them than these actors), the story got its point across.

A damn good criminally underrated movie. A good all around ensemble performance. A great soundtrack. A better then most biopic. One of the surprising films of 2009. Notorious. If you can get past the excessive language and constant dropping of the N word, not that matters because black people can say that all they want, then this movie will leave you hypnotized. (I had to use that kind of clever but not really that clever pun) See this movie.
The guy they got looked and sounded like Biggie....It was soooo good.

Think of it as a Horatio Rapper tale, a truly American Rags to Bling story that encompasses all of the finest elements of a good bio-pic. The material is honest and heartfeltfor the lead actor, this assessment goes tenfold. Best of all, like the best of the genre, the film is more interested in its subjects eventful life than controversial death. Perhaps, the film could have been even more warts-and-all and less like a filmstrip, but the story that results is never boring. Buoyed by an amazingly dead-on performance, Notorious is everything an invigorating biography should be.

In this R-rated bio-pic, the life and violent death of East Coast rapper Christopher Wallace, AKA Notorious B.I.G. (Woolard), is chronicled. 

The film takes a definite vantage point, albeit in successive cradle-to-grave chapters. And this is not to say that the film should have embraced a manic, non-linear, cross cutting approach a la NixonNotoriouss style is in its straightforwardness. Oftentimes, the flick feels like a music video, which would normally be met with cries of foul by your reviewer. Given the fact that the breadth of the story takes place during the MTV Age, however, this manner serves the material perfectly. Though the material drives alongside his drug-selling, two-timing, and warring with fellow rapper Tupac Shakur, the script never crashes head-on into the overall issue of angel or devil. Instead, it arguably takes a definite biased stand, elevating its subject to pariah. There is no debating the star-making turn by Woolard, however. His brilliant performance rings of realism.

Bottom line: Noteworthy but not hypnotic.

A very powerful story about Christopher Wallace aka The Notorious B.I.G. He Goes from nothing to something with the help from some powerful moving people such as Puff Daddy and the whole Bad Boy Records crew.

The movie goes over all the major points in his life and shows a lot of the struggles he went though to get where he was. His life is tragically cut short and the movie ends on a high note of how he influenced a lot of people.

The only gripe I have with the film is that it is a little biased. This is very apparent with the whole 2Pac incident with making everyone look super innocent and all the West Coast rappers looking super bad. It all makes sense in the end but cmon there had to be more going on but lets face it no one will know.

Overall, a pretty good bio-pic on one of the greatest east coast rappers ever.

This biopic is all over the place. It moralizes too much, and it doesn't answer big questions, like what did Big really think, and how were his songs produced. What path was he really on? This film just makes Big's mother and Sean Combs look good for posterity.The only authentic voice is in the music.

This certainly doesn't feel like an Oscar Bio-pic oh no! That's the exact reason why I enjoyed "Notorious" it's not trying to be something it's not, instead it tell the story of Christopher Wallace with great entertainment.
It's good but not 4 KIDS
Decent enough biography. Although sometimes it feels like they are just trying to cram in as man 90s Bad Boy records as possible.
great movie, not just because I love Biggie, but it shed light on such a controversial subject, exposed some truth and told a beautiful story.
Surprisingly enjoyable and not as one-sided as I expected. I am a bit of a fan of Biggie and this film shows him as a genius but definitely with flaws.

As far a music biopics go, no better or worse than most of the others. Biggie is well cast and the acting is solid from everyone. But some of the actors don't look anything like their real-life counterparts and I found that distracting. Also, I wish the movie took more risks, since this is such an interesting story. But it's all pretty straight-forward (even though this is based on real stuff, much of the drama still feels cliche- drugs, sex, money, etc). The East Coast/West Coast rivalry is the best part and it seems like they rush through it. I wanted a little more from this film
